title: Sheila Nelson
text:
Sheila Mary Nelson (5 March 1936 – 16 November 2020) was an English musician, music educator, writer and composer. She had played with the <a href="English%20Chamber%20Orchestra">English Chamber Orchestra</a>, the <a href="Royal%20Philharmonic%20Orchestra">Royal Philharmonic Orchestra</a> and the Menuhin Festival Orchestra but was best known as a <a href="violin">violin</a> and <a href="viola">viola</a> teacher. She is usually referred to as Sheila Nelson but appears in her published works as Sheila M. Nelson.
Biography.
Nelson studied at the <a href="Royal%20College%20of%20Music">Royal College of Music</a> and had a <a href="Bachelor%20of%20Music">B.Mus</a> degree from <a href="London%20University">London University</a>. She also studied at the <a href="University%20of%20Birmingham">University of Birmingham</a> and in Denmark. In 1976 she went to the United States on a <a href="Churchill%20Fellowship">Churchill Fellowship</a> to study with the eminent <a href="string%20instrument">string</a> pedagogue <a href="Paul%20Rolland">Paul Rolland</a>, and in the 1980s directed an innovative group-teaching project in the <a href="London%20Borough%20of%20Tower%20Hamlets">London Borough of Tower Hamlets</a>. The Tower Hamlets Project taught strings and piano to whole school classes in a deprived area of London, and was featured in a six-part TV documentary series, "Beginners Please".
Nelson was co-author of the "Essential String Method" series and author/composer of many other music instruction and repertoire books, published by <a href="Boosey%20%26amp%3B%20Hawkes">Boosey & Hawkes</a>. She was an Honorary Member of the <a href="Royal%20Academy%20of%20Music">Royal Academy of Music</a> (Hon RAM), a distinction limited to 300 musicians.
Nelson died aged 84 on 16 November 2020 having lived with Alzheimer's disease in her final years.
